Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Prepare sermons and deliver weekly messages during Shabbat services.
Situation2: The regular weekly Shabbat service is approaching.
Story: I stood in the kitchen, sleeves rolled up, scrubbing the counter for the third time. My spouse called from the living room, “Can you help me move the chairs? My cousins will be here in an hour.” I glanced at the clock—just two hours until Shabbat. My mind raced with unfinished sermon notes, the Torah portion swirling in my head, half-formed ideas begging for my attention. The expectation to make our home spotless pressed on me, but so did the weight of my congregation’s anticipation for a meaningful message. I could hear my spouse’s footsteps, the tension in their voice as they asked again for help. I wanted to be present, to share the load, to show I cared about our home and our family. But the sacred responsibility of guiding my community tugged at me, demanding focus and solitude. My heart pounded as I stood between the broom and my books, feeling the pull of both worlds, knowing I couldn’t give either the attention they deserved.
